🤖 Micro:bit Python Programming Summary

What is a Micro:bit? A small computer that can be programmed using Python to create interactive projects with sensors, buttons, lights, and wireless communication.

🚀 Getting Started

This part explains how to set up and write your first Python program on the Micro:bit.

Basic Setup

from microbit import * while True: display.scroll("Hello, World!")
  • from microbit import * - Import all micro:bit functions
  • while True: - Create an infinite loop
  • Use 4 spaces for indentation (Tab key)
  • Test in simulator first, then on device

Display Functions

# Show text display.show("Hello") display.scroll("Long message") # Show images display.show(Image.HEART) display.show(Image.HAPPY) display.show(Image.SAD) # Pause between actions sleep(1000) # 1 second
Available Images: HEART, HAPPY, SAD, SILLY, ANGRY, CONFUSED, YES, NO, and many more!

🎮 Input and Decisions

Use this when you need to read buttons or check conditions in your code.

Button Input

from microbit import * while True: if button_a.is_pressed(): display.show(Image.HAPPY) elif button_b.is_pressed(): display.show(Image.SAD) else: display.show(Image.SILLY)

Combining Conditions

# Both buttons pressed if button_a.is_pressed() and button_b.is_pressed(): display.show(Image.HEART) # Either button pressed if button_a.is_pressed() or button_b.is_pressed(): display.show(Image.HAPPY)

Other Sensors

  • accelerometer.was_gesture("shake") - Detect shaking
  • temperature() - Get temperature in Celsius
  • compass.heading() - Get direction
  • pin0.is_touched() - Touch sensor on pins

📊 Variables and Data Types

This shows how to create and use different types of data like numbers and text.

Creating Variables

# Different data types name = "Alice" # String (text) age = 15 # Integer (whole number) height = 1.65 # Float (decimal) is_student = True # Boolean (True/False)
String
Text in quotes
"Hello"
Integer
Whole numbers
42
Float
Decimal numbers
3.14
Boolean
True or False
True

Variable Operations

# Math operations result = 5 + 3 # Addition result = 10 - 4 # Subtraction result = 6 * 2 # Multiplication result = 8 / 2 # Division # Increment shortcut count = 0 count += 1 # Same as count = count + 1 # String operations name = "Bob" message = name * 3 # "BobBobBob"

Converting Data Types

# String to number age = "15" age_int = int(age) # Convert to integer age_float = float(age) # Convert to float # Number to string score = 100 message = "Score: " + str(score)

🌡️ Temperature Projects

Learn to read the temperature sensor and display its value.

Basic Temperature Display

from microbit import * while True: temp = temperature() display.show(temp) sleep(2000)

Temperature Converter

from microbit import * while True: temp_c = temperature() temp_f = temp_c * 9/5 + 32 display.scroll("C: " + str(temp_c)) sleep(1000) display.scroll("F: " + str(temp_f)) sleep(1000)

Temperature Categories

from microbit import * while True: temp = temperature() if temp < 15: display.scroll("Cold") elif temp < 25: display.scroll("Mild") else: display.scroll("Hot") sleep(3000)
Formula: Celsius to Fahrenheit
fahrenheit = celsius * 9/5 + 32

📡 Radio Communication

This section teaches how Micro:bits can send messages to each other.

Basic Radio Setup

from microbit import * import radio radio.on() # Turn on radio radio.config(group=1) # Set group (0-255) while True: # Receive messages incoming = radio.receive() if incoming: display.scroll(incoming)

Sending Messages

from microbit import * import radio radio.on() radio.config(group=1) while True: if button_a.is_pressed(): radio.send("Hello!") display.show("S") # Show sent sleep(1000) # Also listen for messages incoming = radio.receive() if incoming: display.scroll(incoming)
Radio Groups: Only devices with the same group number can communicate. Use different groups (0-255) to create separate networks.

Advanced Messaging

# Send different messages if button_a.is_pressed(): radio.send("Hello") elif button_b.is_pressed(): radio.send("Goodbye") elif accelerometer.was_gesture("shake"): radio.send("Shaking!")

🔐 Encryption & Security

Find out ways to keep your radio messages private and safe.

Caesar Cipher Concept

A simple encryption where each letter is shifted by a fixed number of places in the alphabet.

Example (shift by 3):
A → D, B → E, C → F
"HELLO" → "KHOOR"

Why Encryption?

  • Radio messages can be intercepted by anyone
  • Groups provide some privacy but not full security
  • Encryption scrambles messages so only intended recipients can read them
  • Both sender and receiver need the same "key" to encrypt/decrypt

Programming Dictionaries

# Dictionary for encryption cipher = { 'A': 'D', 'B': 'E', 'C': 'F', 'D': 'G', 'E': 'H', 'F': 'I' # ... and so on } # Usage encrypted_letter = cipher['A'] # Returns 'D'
Project Idea: Create a program that encrypts messages before sending via radio and decrypts received messages!

🛠️ Micro:bit Hardware Features

Discover the built-in parts of the Micro:bit and how to use them.

LED Display
5×5 grid of lights for showing images and text
Buttons A & B
Two programmable buttons for user input
Accelerometer
Detects movement, shaking, and orientation
Temperature Sensor
Measures ambient temperature in Celsius
Compass
Determines direction (North, South, East, West)
Radio/Bluetooth
Wireless communication with other devices
25 Pins
Connect to external sensors and devices
USB Port
For programming and power from computer

💡 Common Patterns

See simple example programs that show useful coding patterns.

Counter Program

from microbit import * count = 0 while True: if button_a.was_pressed(): count += 1 elif button_b.was_pressed(): count -= 1 elif accelerometer.was_gesture("shake"): count = 0 display.show(count) sleep(100)

State Machine

from microbit import * mode = "happy" while True: if button_a.was_pressed(): if mode == "happy": mode = "sad" else: mode = "happy" if mode == "happy": display.show(Image.HAPPY) else: display.show(Image.SAD)

🐛 Debugging Tips

Get help on finding and fixing mistakes in your programs.

Common Errors

  • Syntax Error: Misspelled keywords, missing colons
  • Indentation Error: Wrong spacing (use Tab key)
  • Name Error: Using undefined variables or functions
  • Logic Error: Code runs but doesn't do what you expect

Debugging Strategies

  • Always test in the simulator first
  • Check red underlines and error messages
  • Use display.show() to see variable values
  • Add sleep() to slow down fast loops
  • Check indentation carefully
Pro Tip: The editor suggests code as you type. Press Enter to accept suggestions and avoid typos!

🎯 Project Ideas

Explore fun ideas for projects you can build with the Micro:bit.

Digital Pet
Create a pet that reacts to buttons and shows different emotions
Step Counter
Use the accelerometer to count steps while walking
Compass
Show an arrow pointing North using the compass sensor
Temperature Monitor
Alert when temperature goes above or below certain values
Secret Messenger
Send encrypted messages between micro:bits using radio
Rock Paper Scissors
Shake to generate random choices and play with friends
Reaction Timer
Test how quickly you can press a button after seeing an image
Music Player
Use buttons to play different tunes and sounds
